raw_text:
Kennedy to make temple address
 
 Charles Kennedy is set to address 2,000 people at a Hindu temple as part of an appeal to ethnic minority voters.
 
 The Liberal Democrat leader will visit the Shri Swaminarayan Mandir Temple in Neasden, north west London. He will say Labour "can no longer lay exclusive claim to the votes of Britain's ethnic minorities". Mr Kennedy will also highlight the anger among people of "all races" over the Iraq war and call for a "balanced approach" to tackling terrorism. Saturday's speech comes days after the Lib Dems launched their ethnic minority mini-manifesto. Mr Kennedy is to tell the audience: "Many people in Britain, of all races, cultures and religions, were angry about the way we were taken to war in Iraq. "And they saw the principled stand the Liberal Democrats took at the time."
 
 He will also say that the Lib Dems want to "restore Britain's reputation on the world stage" by fighting international poverty and climate change, and protecting human rights. Mr Kennedy will say that a "balanced approach" to tackling terrorism would mean "tough measures to make Britain safe - but not at the expense of people's fundamental legal rights like has happened at Belmarsh". He will say it also means acting through the United Nations on terrorism. Mr Kennedy held talks with Tony Blair on Friday over government plans to hold terror suspects under house arrest. He said afterwards that the Prime Minister had offered some "movement" to address his concerns. The plans face trouble in the Lords if Conservative and Lib Dem opposition continues.
llama3.2:1b: Charles Kennedy will speak at a Hindu temple in London as part of an appeal for ethnic minority voters, criticizing Labour's exclusive claim to their votes and calling for a balanced approach to tackling terrorism. He will highlight the anger over the Iraq war and his party's principled stance on the issue, and also criticize government plans to hold terror suspects under house arrest, citing concerns over human rights.

The Liberal Democrat leader will say Labour can no longer claim exclusive votes from Britain's ethnic minorities. He will also highlight anger over the Iraq war and call for a balanced approach to tackling terrorism, protecting human rights, and fighting poverty and climate change.

He also met with Tony Blair regarding plans for house arrest of terror suspects.

He plans to emphasize a balanced approach to tackling terrorism without compromising on human rights. Kennedy also mentioned discussions with Tony Blair about government plans for holding terror suspects under house arrest, noting some progress but facing opposition in the Lords.

He said afterwards that the Prime Minister had offered some "movement" to address his concerns. The plans face trouble in the Lords if Conservative and Lib Dem opposition continues.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Charles Kennedy visiting a Hindu temple and some political statements he's making. First, I'll read through the text carefully to understand the main points.

He's setting up an address at a temple with 2,000 people, aiming to appeal to ethnic minority voters. That seems clear. The leader is a Liberal Democrat and will be talking about how Labour can't be exclusive in Britain for minority votes, which is a bit unusual but important.

He mentions the Iraq War anger and a balanced approach to terrorism. He argues against Belmarsh's tough measures regarding terrorism because he believes that making sure people have fundamental rights isn't enough. That's a key point where he calls for a balanced strategy.

Also, he talks about promoting Britain's reputation on the world stage by fighting poverty and climate change, which is an interesting angle. He plans to address these issues in his speech.

He has some interactions with Tony Blair over government plans to arrest terror suspects, but those discussions are facing trouble, especially if both parties oppose him. That shows the political stakes involved.

Now, I need to condense all this into a concise summary without adding any explanations or formatting. I should keep only the key ideas and details from each paragraph.
</think>

Charles Kennedy is visiting a Hindu temple with 2,000 people to appeal to ethnic minority voters. He will speak about Labour not being exclusive in Britain's votes for minorities and highlight anger over the Iraq War and a balanced approach to terrorism, emphasizing fundamental human rights. He plans to address issues like poverty and climate change and criticize Belmarsh's tough tactics regarding terrorism. He also discussed government plans to hold terror suspects under house arrest with Tony Blair, facing opposition from both parties.
tinyllama:1.1b: Charles Kennedy, who is set to make a temple address on May 12th as part of an appeal for ethnic minority voters, will speak about Labour's "exclusive claim" over the votes of these groups, particularly in relation to Iraq and international poverty, and their aim of restoring Britain's status on the world stage. Kennedy will also address the need for a balanced approach to tackling terrorism, including acting through UN measures on terror suspects held under house arrest. The mini-Manifesto launched by the Liberal Democrats last month aims to provide "profound moral clarity" on their position on Iraq and international poverty. These concerns were highlighted during discussions with Tony Blair in advance of the Prime Minister's decision to hold suspects under house arrest.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Charles Kennedy is expected to address a Hindu temple event as part of an appeal to ethnic minority voters. He will share with the audience that Labour cannot continue to claim exclusivity among Britain's ethnic minorities. Instead, he plans to highlight the anger and dissatisfaction over the Iraq war, and call for a more balanced approach to addressing terrorism. Kennedy will also discuss his party's commitment to fighting international poverty and climate change through international agreements and practical measures. He plans to highlight these issues as a way to restore Britain's reputation on the world stage while protecting fundamental legal rights, such as people's rights to basic legal protections like those afforded by the United Nations in cases of terrorism.
phi:2.7b: Charles Kennedy will deliver a speech at the Hindu temple in London, calling for ethnic minority voters to support the Liberal Democrats and highlighting their principled stance on the Iraq war and terrorism. He will also emphasize the need for a balanced approach to tackling these issues and making Britain safe without violating people's fundamental legal rights. The speech comes days after the Lib Dems launched an ethnic minority mini-manifesto, and Mr Kennedy will call for the government to work through the United Nations on international terrorism.

He will also speak out against the Iraq war and the erosion of legal rights under current government policies.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader, is scheduled to speak at the Shri Swaminarayan Mandir Temple in Neasden, addressing 2,000 people. His address aims to appeal to ethnic minority voters and contest Labour's exclusive claim over their support. Kennedy will express dissatisfaction with Britain's involvement in the Iraq war among diverse communities and emphasize the Liberal Democrats' principled stance against it.

He will outline the party's ethnic minority manifesto, focusing on restoring Britain's global reputation by combating poverty, climate change, and human rights abuses. Kennedy will advocate for a balanced approach to terrorism, combining robust security measures with respect for fundamental legal rights, avoiding the precedent set at Belmarsh. He also mentioned discussing government plans to detain terror suspects under house arrest with Prime Minister Tony Blair, hoping for concessions that could prevent potential obstacles in Parliament.
reference: Mr Kennedy will also highlight the anger among people of "all races" over the Iraq war and call for a "balanced approach" to tackling terrorism.Charles Kennedy is set to address 2,000 people at a Hindu temple as part of an appeal to ethnic minority voters.Mr Kennedy will say that a "balanced approach" to tackling terrorism would mean "tough measures to make Britain safe - but not at the expense of people's fundamental legal rights like has happened at Belmarsh".Mr Kennedy is to tell the audience: "Many people in Britain, of all races, cultures and religions, were angry about the way we were taken to war in Iraq.He will say it also means acting through the United Nations on terrorism.He will also say that the Lib Dems want to "restore Britain's reputation on the world stage" by fighting international poverty and climate change, and protecting human rights.
